Package gr.forth.ics.jbenchy.diagram.gnuplot

Provides support for generating gnuplot diagrams from reports generated by Aggregator.

See:
          Description

Class Summary
GnuPlotContext A context for gnuplot, i.e.
GnuPlotWriter Utility class that prints files which command gnuplot to generate 1D or 2D diagrams (diagrams which depict the values of a measurement with regards to one or two variables that affect it).
GnuPlotWriter.GnuPlotFiles A container of generated gnuplot files.
PlotStyle Defines a style for drawing datasets in gnuplot.
 

Enum Summary
Pattern An enumeration of patterns for drawing individual points in gnuplot.
 

Package gr.forth.ics.jbenchy.diagram.gnuplot Description

Provides support for generating gnuplot diagrams from reports generated by Aggregator.

Package Specification

Class GnuPlotWriter can be used to create files ready to be feed to gnuplot and generate postscript diagrams. A GnuPlotWriter instance writes one or many diagrams inside a specified folder. For each diagram, two files are needed: a data file, containing the raw data that gnuplot can read, tab-delimitted, and a command (.plt) file which contains gnuplot commands that instruct gnuplot to generate the diagram from a data file. In the end, a "master" plot file can be created (see GnuPlotWriter.createMasterPlotFile(String)), which simply invokes all the previously created command files, so it is more convenient to pass this file for execution by gnuplot, and all diagrams are created in one step.

Gnuplot is quite complicated, and it is not practical to provide a full abstraction of it. Instead, the class GnuPlotContext is provided, which offers additional customization capabilities in the process of diagram generation (or, more accurately, customization of the creation of the gnuplot command files). Also, it provides basic support for styles, that is, one can define a gnuplot style with which to depict a dataset. For example, PlotStyle.points() can be used to create a scatter plot, whereas PlotStyle.lines() connects data points with lines. See below for an example of this working.

An example of usage follows. Assume this preparation exists (which is explained in Aggregator): 

Aggregator aggregator = ...;
Records records = aggregator. ... report(...);
Diagram diagram = DiagramFactory.newDiagram(records)
    .withTitle("My Title")
    .withRangeLabel("Time (milliseconds)");

Important note: If a report is generated by two variables, then at least the first must have number values; this is a gnuplot-specific restriction.

Now, to create the gnuplot files for this diagram, instantiate a writer to a (relative to current directory) folder: 

GnuPlotWriter writer = new GnuPlotWriter(new File("diagramsFolder"));
writer.writeDiagram(diagram, "myDiagram");
This creates a data file and a gnuplot command file in diagramsFolder with names myDiagram1.*

We can customize the gnuplot commands by creating a GnuPlotContext: 

GnuPlotContext context = new GnuPlotContext();
There are various things that can be tweaked, like setting variables and style for columns. For example, this: 
context.setLogscaleX();
context.setLogscaleY();
will cause the additional gnuplot instructions to appear in the gnuplot command file: 
set logscale x
set logscale y
In order for this to happen, the diagram must be generated like this: 
writer.writeDiagram(diagram, "myDiagram", context);
Generally, context.set("var", "value") will cause set var value to appear in the gnuplot instructions, right before the plot. After that, the variable would be unset by unset var.

The default style for plotting is by connecting subsequent data points with lines, i.e. a simple lines chart. To create a scatter plot, i.e. a plot of plain XY points, try this: 

int variableIndex = 1;
context.setStyle(variableIndex, PlotStyle.points());
Plotting styles can also define a specific drawing pattern (like a cross, a star, a triangle, etc.), like this: //Used to draw the first dataset context.setStyle(1, PlotStyle.points(Pattern.STAR)); //Used to draw the second dataset context.setStyle(2, PlotStyle.lines(Pattern.BOX_FILLED));

A default plotting style can also be defined, that takes effect for all datasets with undefined styles (which can be overriden with a specific style setting). For example: 

context.setDefaultStyle(PlotStyle.points());
